Back in his personal dressing room Thunderbolt took his time to have some food and water, and to just lay down and rest for a moment. Being in serial during the sixties was a lot of hard working if you wanted to become a big star, and it had to come with some "lesser good moments" as well. Because the truth was that Thunderbolt (Just like most of the Dalmatians) thought that this was a very stupid idea for the show. It's scripted to only be throughout this season and then have him changed back to his normal self again in the last episode, but he was already starting to get sick of it right now halfway through.

"If it wasn't for me getting my salary I don't know how much more of this I could take." Thunderbolt thought to himself, as a crewmember entered his room to tell him he was about to be back for recording. Thunderbolt tried to get up on his own but found the suit keeping him down on his back, so he had the crew member helping him to roll over so he could get on all four. "Another thing this stupid thing does to make things harder for me." He though as he got himself to the sets.

Where should the story go now?
1553322222122112.title: Behind the fatsuit.

choices: The Spoiled Life of a Celebrity...
Publicity! Get his shape in the Paper!
155332222212212.content:
Okay, So Thunderbolt the Star shall become a Large Canine.

How or Why would he get this Large, though?
155332222212212.title: The actor.

1553322222122121.content:
How does his Celebrity status make him gain?

The Show being sponsored by a brand of "Kanine Krunchies", which Thunderbolt has to eat, but with the side effct of that they're really fattening?

Or...

So much Leisure and Party Life?
1553322222122121.title: The Spoiled Life of a Celebrity...

15533222221221212.content: Before or after he met Patch?
15533222221221212.title: Leisure Time?

155332222212212122.content:
Thunderbolt's television career was over. A set accident had crushed his leg and made him walk with a limp. The veterinarian had said that Thunderbolt would never walk normally again. After five years of television screening, just as Thunderbolt was reaching the peak of his ratings, this had happened. A set man had had some Jack Daniel's on the job and had knocked over a light, which had fallen on Thunderbolt's leg and had crushed it. Thunderbolt only knew, however, that his leg hurt miserably.
         When he was discharged, there was no media coverage, no attention, no praise, just quiet, which Thunderbolt appreciated if he was honest with himself. When Thunderbolt's handler had phoned the studio, the manager said that he would ask around and see if anyone wanted to adopt Thunderbolt. After a few days of no response, Thunderbolt's handler decided to put up an add in The Times to see if someone wanted a former dog television star.
         Having phoned The Times, Thunderbolt's handler waited for a day.


         Roger was looking through the morning paper catching up on how Labor was doing in the polls when he stumbled into the classified section and saw a small advertisement that caught his eye. "Anita, dear," he called, "Anita, when you have a moment, would you come see?" When he got a response, he went back to looking at the advertisement that read thus, "Former dog televison actor in need of good home."
         When Anita appeared, Roger handed her the paper and pointed out the advertisement. "It looks like Thunderbolt" was all she said. When her husband told her that it was, she looked up and immediately responded, "Oh, no, we can't afford another dog, Roger. They'll have to start living outside." When Roger pointed out that most of them did anyway, Anita huffed and replied, "I suppose that I really can't argue with you, can I? But I expect a favor later." When Roger kissed her, car-key already in hand, she knew the answer. No, there was no reasoning wither her husband when he set his mind, which fortunately wasn't too often.


         When Roger arrived at the address mentioned, he realized perhaps that he should have left more than a name and message that he was coming for Thunderbolt with the woman, but it was too late for that now, he realized. It was a shabby part of London, a housing project, formerly called a slum, which Roger nearly called it. Perhaps it wouldn't be too terrible, he thought. He went to the designated address and heard the din of raucous children inside. Roger found raucous children distasteful and grimaced at the thought.
         Suddenly, he saw a woman carrying an apparently three-year-old child in her arms. She looked tired and disgruntled. "What is it ya want?" she spat in the same derisive tone that Roger was hearing all around him. "Hi," Roger began, "I'm here to pay for Thunderbolt. Do I have the right address?" When the woman nodded, ahe set the child down and grabbed a leash and pulled a limping dog with a cone on him out of her house, which smelled worse than the dog himself did.
         Roger picked up the dog and set him gently in his car and drove back home.
155332222212212122.title: After

1553322222122121221.content:
Thunderbolt awoke groggily to the car's stopping. The car door opened and he smelled vaguely familiar smells of dogs whom he sensed that he had once met. A man, a gentle man, based on how carefully he held Thunderbolt, carried him up to a house, a rather large house which smelled of dogs, who were now barking madly. "Quiet!" Roger shouted at them, and they all ceased barking immediately. Roger fumbled with his pocket and finally managed to extract some keys, put them in the door, open the door, and set Thunderbolt down carefully.
         The room was still eerily silent. All of the dogs, every single one Thunderbolt saw, was a Dalmatian, all adults now. One in particular, however, Thunderbolt recognized. "Are you," the Dalmatian asked, stultified seemingly by Thunderbolt's arrival, "Thunderbolt? The actor from that show, what was it called? Anyway, are you Thunderbolt?" Thunderbolt lowered his head in shame, "I was. but now I have this," Thunderbolt gestured at his caste, "it's untreatable." "Well, anyway," the Dalmatian continued, "I'm Patch, and these are my parents," gesturing to Pongo and Perdita, "and my 98 siblings. Welcome to our home."
         When it seemed that everyone had forgotten about him, Thunderbolt took a snooze. But when he awoke, the living room was empty except for one Dalmatian. "Goo' afternoon," Thunderbolt yawned to the Dalmatian who lay down a few feet away. The Dalmatian stood, meandered a bit closer, close enough to have a quiet conversation, and inquired, "What brings you here? I don't mean to be rude, but why aren't you still a movie star?"
         Thunderbolt chuckled, "Did you hear me say that this can't be healed?" When the other dog shook his head and asked pardon for talking about such sensitive matters, Thunderbolt chuckled and looked at the other Dalmatian, "Why aren't you playing with your other siblings? Don't worry about me. I'll be just fine on my own. Go run around." Rolly let out a sigh, "Do you wanna know why they call me 'Rolly'? It's because I'm fat. I've been this way all my life. I get tired way more easily than my siblings do, I can't keep up with them, and they tease, which makes me want to drown out the teasing with food. Never mind that I am just as smart, if not smarter, better at debating, or better at arguing. They call me fat, everyone laughs, and I get ignored by everyone."
         "Maybe you should try to lose some weight. I mean, you aren't exactly thin," Thunderbolt suggested, trying to be helpful. But Rolly only gave the sarcastic laugh that says that he didn't actually think someone has said something funny, only so dumb as to elicit a chuckle. "I'm sorry," he sighed, "When I said that I always was the way that I am now, that wasn't quite true. For six months I lost weight and kept it off; but the fat jokes never stopped or even slowed. They've always come in the same number. So losing weight wasn't the solution."
         Thunderbolt was impressed, "Well, why didn't you keep it off? You just proved them right; you just quit." "You know," Thunderbolt said, thoroughly demoralized but having an idea dawn on him, "I think I have a way of dealing with these little buggers who won't leave you alone."
1553322222122121221.title: The Arrival of Thunderbolt.

15533222221221212211.content:
The anesthetic was wearing off. Thunderbolt's appetite was returning to him. Rolly explained that the only way to feed all the dogs was to free feed them in a large trough of food in the kitchen. No other dog or human was inside on such a beautiful summer day, so Thunderbolt went in and ate hismself full of dog food. He hadn't let in Rolly on his plan, but soon enough Thunderbolt was sure that Rolly would catch on if he were as smart as claimed he was.
         When everyone came in, Thunderbolt hobbled near, but not next to Rolly to get to the food line. The crowd allowed Thunderbolt to eat whatever he liked before it returned to its shoving. Rolly, who had been smart and had waited til just before and just after everyone had left before he gorged himself on the food in the trough. Now thoroughly full, Thunderbolt hobbled over and plopped down in his previous seat. And the crowd got down to talking. Rolly and Patch, Thunderbolt noticed, were in a heated, well, Thunderbolt noted, only Patch was upset.
         Tension finally reached the point where Patch yelled, "Why am I even talking to you, you overgrown self-righteous prick!" Everyone who had not been watching the conversation turned and laughed and jeered. "Perhaps," Thunderbolt interjected in the jeers with a raised voice, "when one resorts to name-calling in an argument, one has already lost the argument." Rolly didn't smirk, but he smiled a bit for just a second, just enough for Thunderbolt and no one else to see it before he had smothered it again, the best thing he could have done before he glared for a momentat Thunderbolt, which everyone but Thunderbolt thought was Rolly's first reaction.
         "Thunderbolt, I didn't need your help, but thank you." He stormed out of the room, and Thunderbolt didn't follow him. Later, however, Thunderbolt found Rolly stuffing his face at the trough with no one around but the two of them. Thunderbolt followed suit; and when Both finished, Thunderbolt got down to business, "That was wonderful acting and the best amateur show that I've ever seen." Rolly walked out gingerly with his hips swaying back and forth before he gestured for Thunderbolt to follow him. "It's not safe there. People can hear you. Come to the barn. There's old food there too."
         Rolly and Thunderbolt were both out of breath when they reached the barn, albeit for different reasons. Rolly opened the door and walked over to a closet and grabbed and swallowed a mouthful of oats from a horse feed bag and quickly lay down on the dirt floor. "I'm glad that you read into my ploy. I guess that being an actor helped. Thanks, though. Maybe now people will respect your opinion because it disagrees with mine. That was beautiful though. Are you ok?" When Thunderbolt had nodded, Rolly offered him the oats, which were a tad stale but still wholesome and tasty. He glad ate a few mouthfuls.
         "But there was something else that I wanted to tell you," Thunderbolt added before they left back to the house, "I'm trying to help you remove the stigma from your head by trying to gain a little weight myself. I'm old, I've had fame, what good am I anyway. I'm…" he never would say disabled. "Injured?" Rolly tried, and Thunderbolt liked it, "injured," he finished. Rolly chuckled sadly before he retorted, "Look, sir, are you sure about this? Mine was a lonely and sad life before this. Do you really want to be ostrasized forever? You're a former movie star; go be popular with my family, don't stay here with the sad, fat loser like me."
         Thunderbolt nodded, "Too damn bad, kiddo. I'm tired of living like a twig and eating like one. I want to be free and eat freely."
15533222221221212211.title: Let's hear it.

155332222212212122111.content:
After six weeks, when the doctor cut off Thunderbolt's caste, he did a general examination as well. "Well, his leg still hasn't healed completely, but the bone is; so he will have a limp for the rest of his life. I hate to break this to you, but it's best that we tell you the straight truth. And you may want to manage Thunderbolt's weight, it could become a complication if gets too big. He's fine now; I understand why he has gained a few pounds from being unused to being sedentary, but he should slim down soon, so just watch him a bit and make sure he does."
         Roger listened, thanked the doctor for his advice, and walked Thunderbolt to the car to go home. At least this time, Thunderbolt noted, he didn't have a cone on and wasn't woozy when he left the vet's office. Roger looked at the bill and face-palmed himself: this was why he didn't too often come to the veterinarian.
         Back at his home, Thunderbolt waited until everyone had left the kitchen by spying on it from his spot in the living room before he mozied over to the trough and ate a normal meal. The six weeks had passed slowly, with eating, sleeping, and talking being the only things he could do. He could barely go outside to relieve himself before Roger dragged him back inside.
         Now, however, he had a limp, which made his polite refusal to play seem plausible. He would sometimes wander with Rolly to the barn for the seemingly endless supply of oats that satisfied Thunderbolt when he didn't want to risk being seen eating or wanted to seem like he wanted to play but couldn't. With a bit of relish, however, Thunderbolt noticed that he had started only now to begin losing his movie-star's physique. His ribs didn't show when he turned as much as he could, which was less now than it was with his normal physique thanks to the small roll of flesh that formed when he tried to chase his tail.
         These were the subtle things that Thunderbolt noticed were happening to himself. Of course, Thunderbolt marvelled, he looked nothing like Rolly, who had a barrel-shaped appearance and a "pigeon chest," as humans called it. Little dimples of flesh formed at his haunces when he sat; to Thunderbolt, Rolly looked like an adorable puppy still, despite obviously being three years old. Thunderbolt pondered for a second that he was, in fact, six-years-old and was middle-aged.
         The barn was situated on a little hill that always nearly caused Thunderbolt to laugh when it caused Rolly to begin to pant simply by going up it. He chuckled to himself; he was only a bit winded because he was an injured old man. Rolly was a healthy young man. "Here we are," Rolly exhaled after drawing a deep breath. Thunderbolt was amused by the young man's attempts not to sound winded, which were obviously not working.
         "So, how many bags of oats are left?" Thunderbolt asked Rolly, who answered, "I estimate 1 or 2." Thunderbolt knew immediately that this was a lie, despite Rolly's unchanged tone. And then Thunderbolt heard it: footsteps. Someone knew about their hiding spot and was spying on them. "Excuse me," Thundebolt said, "I need to relieve myself; I'll be right back." Rolly nodded, understanding the not-too-subtle hint Thunderbolt was leaving him. Thunderbolt knew exactly where the noise had come from, so he went to that side of the barn and found…
155332222212212122111.title: And so Thunderbolt does.

1553322222122121221111.content:
Patch must have sensed Thunderbolt's approach too late because the poor dog was scared stiff when Thunderbolt jumped on top of him. "What are you doing here?" Thunderbolt growled. "I--sir, I saw you and my brother go in to the barn together and I wondered what you were doing," the poor dog stammered, "Leave. If he knows you're spying on him, he'll think that I'm a spy. I want him to lose weight, but I need you to not blow my cover. Please, just go; and don't tell anyone. Rumor is a horrible monster."
         With that, Patch left in a bit of a hurry. Thunderbolt rushed back inside. "Look," Thunderbolt stammered to Rolly, "we have to go soon. I don't trust your brother not to blabber." But Rolly looked calm, "Ok, but we have to eat this entire bag of oats or else they'll have evidence." Thunderbolt agreed until he looked at the bag, which was still 3/4 full. "I'm quite hungry," Thunderbolt muttered to himself, and the two dogs quickly began to devour the contents of the bag. Thunderbolt began to worry that the troop was coming. Only a quarter of the bag remained, but Thunderbolt's stomach already felt distended. Rolly, however, managed to fit the remaining oats into his stomach. Thunderbolt knocked over the trash can and quickly stuffed the bag and the spilled contents back in.
         When that was finished, Rolly scrambled with the lock until he had locked the door to the feed room. Both dogs sat panting for a moment before they heard the playful noises of Patch and his brothers, who seemed to be scouting the land playfully, but Thunderbolt sensed why Patch had really come, and he sensed that Rolly knew. Rolly was sleeping when Patch opened the door and called, "Hey, does either of you two want to come and scout the farm with us? Mr. Thunderbolt, if your leg hurts, we don't want to exacerbate that pain. Rolly, do you wanna come?"
         Rolly, who had only heard his brother's story hazily, stretched lying down and replied, "No, thank you, though. I was fine talking with Mr. Thunderbolt's company." Patch laughed menacingly, "Ha, that isn't true. You were eating oats and sleeping in the barn. Don't lie!" "Boys," Thunderbolt interjected, "it's not nice to lie about someone like that. He was just talking to me. I know, Patch, that your overheard discussion of ours sounded nefarious, but Rolly was doing no such thing, only daydreaming, in his usual way, that he had the oats that we know are in the back closet of the barn."
         Patch looked thoroughly beaten and left before he could show it to his siblings. "Thank you, sir," Rolly intoned sleepily, before sleeping off his oats. "Rolly," Thunderbolt whispered, "return later tonight. Make sure Patch sees you go. Don't eat any of the oats, but scratch at the locked door; and if he reveals himself, appear startled to see him." Rolly nodded before his eyes glazed over and the two of them dozed off together.


         That night, Rolly made sure that everyone was asleep, including Thunderbolt, before he began his plan. Patch had almost fallen perfectly for his plan: he slept near the back door away from other dogs, he was a light sleeper, and he opened his eyes just enough to let Rolly know that he had seen him. But Rolly didn't show Patch enough of his head to let him see that he had been noticed, but he indeed had been noticed.
         Rolly plodded over to the barn in the cool autumnizing air. When he got there, he weezed and forced open the door, leaving it open a crack when he closed it. It made too much noise to close it all the way. At the door for the oats, he did exactly as Thunderbolt had told him to, he whined and scratched at the door, pretending to hope that someone would open it for him.
         Rolly could almost feel Patch watching him. And then Patch made the fatal mistake: he rearranged his position and knocked the door. Rolly spun around, embarrassed that his brother was so clumsy and stupid. "Patch?" Rolly said in feigned surprise, "What are you doing here?" "That's my questionto you," Patch spat back at Rolly. "I'm sorry," Rolly whined, "did I disturb you with my futile wishes? If I did, then please excuse my lack of deftness. You know that I've always been a bit clumsy."
         Patch scowled, shook his head, and traisped off to bed, too tired or perhaps to dumb to see through the ploy. How was this his brother? Rolly asked himself.


         The next morning, when the two were alone and no one was spying on them, Thunderbolt whispered, "how many bags of oats are there?" This time, Rolly replied, "I estimate forty or fifty, which should last us through the winter. After that, I have no idea what we'll do." Thunderbolt nodded, appreciative of the honesty.
         But rumor was indeed a horrible monster; so Perdita, having full confidence in Patch, heard his report that Rolly had found a secret stash of oats in the barn.
1553322222122121221111.title: Patch.

15533222221221212211111.content:
"Pongo," Perdita whispered to her husband nonchalantly, "do you know where Rolly is?" Pongo's mood turned timid, when his wife asked a question like that, a storm inadvertently was brewing. "No, dear, I don't. Do you want me to find him and bring him to you?" Pongo asked tepidly. "I would appreciate it," was his wife's steely reply. Pongo rushed off to find his son, who did seem to disappear often. Pongo found Rolly dozing with Thunderbolt in the barn, about which Pongo had heard a strange rumor recently reagrding Rolly.
         Pongo nosed Rolly, "Come on, son; your mother wants to see you." Rolly blinked slowly, rolled himself over with what Pongo could only describe as with a touch of difficulty before getting up with a stretch. "Are you ok, Rolly?" Pongo worriedly asked his son who chuckled and responded, "Sorry, I'm tired; I guess I didn't sleep well last night. I sometimes get up slowly to stretch if that's what you're referring to. Mom asked me about it too. It helps me limber up. "
         Pongo shrugged: Rolly's behavior was nothing like his own, but this was just a minor idiosyncrasy that was well within observed behavior. Pongo trotted ahead to not keep wis wife waiting, but Rolly seemed to struggle to keep up with his own father, who was an 8-year-old Dalmatian, a rather old man outrunning a young man. Something was strange, Pongo noted.
         When Pongo got back to Perdita, Rolly seemed out of breath and sat with a thump and panted before he struggled to ask, "You wanted to see me, Mother?" Perdita looked a bit shaken: her husband was only breathing slightly heavier than he usually did and quickly recovered. But Rolly…seemed to live up to his name. When he sat, folds of fat protruded from his abdomen, making a small indent like a reversed hour-glass shape.
         Perdita had no idea where to begin, "Rolly, are you ok?". Rolly shook off the question with a laugh before he scoffed, "Mother, you know that I've never been much for exercise. Why are so surprised? Father has always liked exercise. He still beats Patch at races sometimes." Perdita did see Rolly's point there, amazed at how insightful her son could be. "Rolly, Patch brought me a rumor that I was hoping that you could disspell: have you been eating oats from the barn?" Rolly laughed, shaking the rolls of flesh on his sides, "Yes, mother, I walk through a locked door and eat oats! I wish. You know me so well.
         Not appreciating the sarcasm but appreciating the answer, Perdita dismissed him. "You know," Pongo meandered, "I saw Thunderbolt in the barn too, and he looked like Rolly." Perdita turned, "What does that mean?" she asked, sensing what he meant but wanting to confirm. "He looks a bit…heavy, no?" Perdita considered and stated, "Perhaps he does; but he's not our son. Besides, he's old and crippled, of course he's going to go a bit soft." Pongo was amazed that his usually discrete wife had failed to pick up on his implications. But he decided to let it go. Now was not the time for an argument. Pongo knew that his wife was planning a way to deal with their portly son.
15533222221221212211111.title: Follow this storyline.

155332222212212122111111.content:
Pongo managed to catch Thunderbolt alone in the mid-afternoon, when the former movie-star went out to exercise his leg a bit. "Thunderbolt, good afternoon, is your leg feeling better?" Pongo started. Thunderbolt turned, a bit surprised to see a visitor, "Good afternoon, Pongo, what brings you here?" Pongo replied with something about how he had seen Thunderbolt exercising and was wondering how he was doing in his recovery.
         "Not much has changed," Thunderbolt sighed. Pongo was frequently "just curious", so Thunderbolt was surprised when Pongo continued, "except your weight, that is." Thunderbolt couldn't tell whether Pongo had been joking, so he let out a half-hearted laugh. "You're right, I guess. I had suspected as much, but I wanted someone else to confirm it. I had so many sycophants when I was a star. I never could tell who was being honest with me. I don't have to worry about that with you, I see. Thanks," Thunderbolt sighed a fake sigh of resignation but was secretly elated that someone else had noticed.
         Once again, Thunderbolt expected the conversation to die or switch topics, but was bewildered when Pongo awkwardly interposed with, "Too many oats, huh?" Once more unsure of whether Pongo's comment was meant as a joke, Thunderbolt again responded in the same way, "So, you've heard those rumors too, I see. No, I'm afraid Rolly and my own boredom had too much influence on my wasteline. There's so much food in the trough; it's amazing really." Pongo nodded and got to his main point, "You say Rolly influenced you in some way? How?"
         Thunderbolt chuckled, "If you haven't noticed, your son Rolly enjoys food as much as you enjoy Perdita. But as I said, my own boredom more than anything caused me to eat. There are no accessible oats, by the way. And Rolly just enjoys being in the barn away from the noise of the house and yard. And I'm trying to lose weight again." Pongo kept pressing, however, "You seem to have a lot of sway over Rolly. Perdita is worried about him; could you perhaps influence him to adopt your dietary wish to lose weight?" Thunderbolt smiled, "I'll try, but you overestimate how much influence I have over him."
         Pongo smiled, seemingly satisfied with the result, and walked away. Thunderbolt went back to exercising; so he went longer than usual to look like he was committed to losing weight. But as soon as he was done, he immediately found Rolly, who was sleeping in the barn. "Rolly," Thunderbolt whispered, "we should probably talk soon." Rolly perked up from a half-awake trance, "when and where?" Rolly yawned, stretching and rolling over slowly. "How about at the living room in an hour?" Rolly nodded and drifted back off to sleep; Rolly was a lazy dog, Thunderbolt thought to himself. That was fine, he had nothing better to do anyway.


         The living room was quiet at this time of the day when everyone was outside playing and relaxing, so Thunderbolt and Rolly were alone in the living room. "So, Thunderbolt," Rolly began, nervous to get to the point, "what's up?" Thunderbolt sighed,"Rolly, your parents are worried about you. They think that you ought to lose weight, and they think that I'm on their side. Never forget, and I mean never, that I am always unwaveringly on your side. When we are alone, I'll always be honest; so remember that too. I think we should, to maintain our façades, have you lose a bit of weight before you regain it? Does that sound good?"
         Rolly paused for a moment, appearing to weigh his options, "I think that it serves our strategic interest well. I agree for now." Thunderbolt nodded, "Then let's devise a plan."
155332222212212122111111.title: Pongo questions Thunderbolt.

choices: A few days pass (someone gets suspicious.)
1553322222122121221111111.content:
"The key," Thunderbolt pondered, "is how to get your family, especially your mother, to notice you without making your workout seem fake. You must never tell anyone that you are working out unless someone asks, and you can't do it in brazen places. You have to strike a perfect balance. I will be your eyes and ears and tell you what I hear among your siblings. We must satisfy your parents."
         "You know," Rolly yawned, "we could let this blow over. This seems like a way to stir more interest and a way for them to demand more results." Thunderbolt nodded, "But it doesn't. You don't actually have to lose any weight, you merely have to appear like you're exercising. Maybe, when your mother sees you exercise, but doesn't see you lose weight, she'll lay off your case. But again, you also mustn't eat when anyone else is around. If you do, eat less than you normally do; show restrain; and act like you're on a diet. And also, if you eat when someone else is around, make sure he isn't around when you eat again."
         Rolly nodded, agreeing with Thunderbolt's plan. "I can't promise ease; but I can promise hope," Thunderbolt added, "Come on, let's go get something to eat." And having sated themselves, Rolly went back to the living room to await the next day.


         The next day came swiftly; and Thunderbolt nudged Rolly as the sun was rising before any of his siblings stirred. "The moment we see two of your siblings, we stop and go in the barn," Thunderbolt whispered when the duo got to the barn. Rolly assented, nervous about the exercises. "All right," Thunderbolt said, "Run down the hill and back five times. Is that good?" Rolly replied that he was ready and went off. For the first couple of laps, Rolly seemed to be managing fine, keeping a light run going; but by the fourth relay, he was panting and beginning to drool; and by the fifth lap, he was positively foaming and had slowed to a walk. When Rolly got to the top of the hill, he collapsed, panting and drooling all over the ground. So he was a bit out of shape, Thunderbolt thought to himself, no worries. Rolly's stomach growled, "I'm famished," he grumbled. Thunderbolt chuckled.
         "How about you do 25 jumps in the air. You know, the kind you used to do as a puppy when you were excited," Thunderbolt suggested. Rolly groaned and forced himself up. When Rolly jumped, he got little more than a few inches off the ground. "Higher, Rolly," Thunderbolt encouraged before Rolly tried again, jumping a couple inches higher, "better," Thunderbolt encouraged, "24 more of those." Once again, by the end of the exercises, Rolly close to collapsed. "At least we can go in the barn now," Thunderbolt whispered, having seen Perdita and Pongo watching them.
         "Your parents have noticed," Thunderbolt said as the thoroughly exhausted Dalmatian plodded into the barn. Rolly did one more round of half-heared exercises before he quit, flopping onto his stomach to cool himself off and catch his breath. Thunderbolt meanwhile walked off to get breakfast; and while he was doing that, Perdita came up to him and thanked him, "For what? Exercising him?" When Perdita nodded, Thunderbolt continued, "I'm happy to do that. If you want, I can keep doing it." Perdita giggled, "Why does he listen to you and not Pongo?"
         Thunderbolt pondered, unsure of the answer, "Well, I am a former movie-star that he loved as a child, according to him. And we did spend a lot of time together when I had my cast on. I think he connected with me in that time. And how, I don't know." Perdita nodded, thanked him, and walked off, and Thunderbolt ate his breakfast heartily and went back to check on Rolly when everyone had eaten. "How are you doing?" Thunderbolt asked, actually concerned about Rolly's health. "Tired," Rolly panted, "and near starving." "Then come on," Thunderbolt gestured, "let's go get some breakfast."
         When the two got to the trough, however, Perdita was standing there eating; so Thunderbolt whispered, "Remember, restraint," in case anyone had overheard him. Rolly nodded and only took a few mouthfuls of food before he walked away. Thunderbolt took the opportunity to shove more food into his stomach. Perdita, who had finished, whispered to Thunderbolt after Rolly had walked away, "I'm amazed! How did you get Rolly to restrain himself?" Thunderbolt shrugged and swallowed, "I asked, and he did it." Thunderstruck, Perdita nodded and went outside. Seeing that no one else was inside, Thunderbolt gestured for Rolly to come back into the kitchen; and then Rolly stuffed his face with enough food to give himself a nearly-swollen stomach. "Careful, Rolly, you don't want to throw up," Thunderbolt chortled at Rolly, who stop eating and flopped down in the living room, not bothering to even get on the sofa. So Thunderbolt gingerly raised himself on to the sofa, hindered by his food.
1553322222122121221111111.title: Devising a plan.

choices: Pongo noticed that Rolly had lost some weight.
15533222221221212211111111.content:
Although Pongo noticed remarkable improvement in Rolly's stamina, strength, and endurance, his parents only noticed that Rolly seemed to gain weight. His stomach started out , when he sat, with only a small fold of flesh, which grew larger as the weeks wore on until Rolly's stomach had the slightest bulge even when he stood. Thunderbolt noticed that he himself had begun to fill out. He now had the same cylindrical shape that Rolly had had when Thunderbolt had first arrived at the estate, with a barreling chest and softening sides.
         Although Rolly's fat pad had only increased slightly in size, the growth had discouraged Pongo and Perdita from emphasizing their son's weight loss. Thunderbolt kept telling them that he was getting better results from Rolly, but this was where Pongo and Perdita split: Pongo was sceptical and wanted the exercises to stop, arguing that somehow, perhaps by putting Rolly's body in some type of "starvation mode," which meant that it consumed fewer calories. Perdita, however, seemed to Thunderbolt to so desperately want to believe that her son was just on the precipice of losing weight that she argued for a redoublingof their efforts. Thunderbolt actively sided with Perdita, which he knew would make Pongo that much more stubborn.
         So Thunderbolt let another month pass. It was now mid-February, a cold, wet February. Perdita had made herself a nervous wreck trying to get Rolly to lose weight. She pestered Thunderbolt constantly with questions. For Rolly, however, sneaking food was becoming harder with more people in the house meaning fewer opportunities to eat, so he frequently went to the barn with Thunderbolt to pillage the supply of oats, which dwindled to half their original supply from the previous November.
         Rolly grew worried that they would run out of oats, so Thunderbolt argued that they should save the oats for winter only, and Rolly agreed. Meanwhile, Pongo kept trying to soothe his frantic wife, "Perdita, please, please, you see what the exercise has done to Rolly. Perhaps we should lay off the exercise regimen for Rolly." Perdita kept resisting pointlessly, until Rolly fell down the hill.


         It was mid-march, still cool and icy, but also marshy and wet. The hill was of course no exception. And Rolly, being the klutz that he was, rolled down the hill one day while his mother was watching. The fall hadn't been terrible, and Rolly had only gotten a few nicks and bruises here and there, nothing that wouldn't have healed in a couple of days. But Perdita, being in the frenzied state that she was in, had had a "conversion" and had run over to her son, who said he was ok but feigned some pain.
         Perdita had immediately asked Thunderbolt to stop with the exercise regimen, which Thunderbolt had seemingly reluctantly agreed to. Perdita had then hung her head and gone inside and had curled up in a ball and had sobbed for a few minutes. She would soon, however, accept Rolly's state and would get over her past qualms.
         "Rolly," Thunderbolt whispered, "Now you actuallly need to lose some weight. It doesn't matter how quickly you gain it back so long as your parents notice that you've lost some weight." Rolly sighed, "Thunderbolt, please tell me that this is the final stage of your plan?" Thunderbolt winced, "No, but you have to trust me, ok? It'll be over soon." Rolly nodded, wishing the pain to go away.


         Dieting hurt far more than exercise did, both mentally and physically. The hunger left gnawing pains in Rolly's stomach, and the realization that he couldn't do anything about it made him irritable. He didn't outwardly show it, but he did feel irritation. Thunderbolt, meanwhile, took Rolly's share of the food so that people wouldn't suspect that Rolly was on a diet. That led to many uncomfortable sessions on the couch, wheezing to try and draw a breath because of the volume of the food in his stomach. It hurt, but Thunderbolt wanted his plan to work.
         Perhaps mid-June, shortly after Rolly's fourth birthday, …
15533222221221212211111111.title: A few weeks pass.

155332222212212122111111111.content:
Thunderbolt's injured leg was hurting again. The pain was the prickly, shooting type that makes one want to lie down curled up in a ball and weep bitterly. Thunderbolt knew, however, that he had to ignore the pain. He had accidentally slept on his leg again, and that was the source of his pain. Thunderbolt knew immediately that he wouldn't be able to do his exercises that day. So he stood and hobbled over to the food trough where he took a few mouthfuls of food and hobbled over to see Rolly.
         Pongo, however, had been awoken by Thunderbolt's movements and had risen to see what was happening. Pongo caught up with Thunderbolt outside, "Want some help?" Thunderbolt shook his head, "I'm fine; I just slept on my leg, which now feels uncomfortable. Sorry. Did I disturb you?" Pongo laughed, "It's not as if you meant to; I sleep lightly, perhaps a function of being the one the kids came to when they were sick in the middle of the night when they were younger."
         Thunderbolt nodded, sympathizing with Pongo's claim; but now, having nearly reached the top of the hill, his knees ached; so when he got to the top of the hill, Thunderbolt sat gingerly down on his uninjured leg. Rolly, who had heard the approach, came out and greeted the two of them and sat down near them. His fat dimple caused from his sitting was gone, Pongo noticed with satisfaction. He was perhaps ready again to try to help Rolly lose weight.
         "Rolly," Pongo began after the greeting, "you look like you've lost weight. You look so much better." Rolly grimaced, "Yes, but I feel worse." Pongo frowned, "Don't worry; you'll get over it soon I'm sure." Rolly nearly rolled his eyes, but neither said nor did anything. "Have you perhaps been restricting your eating?" Pongo asked, prodding the issue. Rolly shook his head; so Pongo continued, "Perhaps we could monitor how much you eat and see if that helps?" Rolly grimaced, pretending to loathe his father's advice, "Perhaps," Thunderbolt interjected, "because of my leg, I could monitor the food trough and see how much Rolly eats. Pongo nodded, "but I'll relieve you at times if you want." Thunderbolt laughed, "why not? Let's try it?"
         Rolly knew immediately what he had to do. If his father were guarding the trough, Rolly would restrain himself; but if Thunderbolt were at the trough, Rolly would have his field day. That would help Rolly tremendously.


         Thunderbolt appreciated his duty as sentinel. Pongo would take over being sentinel at night, whereas Thunderbolt would be sentinel during most of the day. Thus, whenever no one else was in the room, except Rolly, of course, Thunderbolt would eat as much food as he could; and he would allow Rolly to do the same. Rolly was delighted to be able to eat as he pleased again, and spent as much time as he could eating when no on else was around.
         It didn't take long for Rolly to gain back the little skin fold that he had once had, and it didn't take too long for Thunderbolt to obtain one for himself. Pongo noticed that Rolly was gaining weight again, so he decided to scrap the project of the diet soon after it had started because he had lost too much sleep from it.
         Pongo, however, decided not to give up on his crusade to get Rolly to lose weight and immediately set out to see what he could do. Pongo tried stealthily watch his son, who never did anything suspicious in front of his father. Pongo couldn't find the missing link. Then, one day, as he watched Thunderbolt walk, waddle was a better description, Pongo thought, he noticed something. When Thunderbolt sat, he had the same fold of skin over his haunches that Rolly had; so he thought…
155332222212212122111111111.title: Pongo noticed that Rolly had lost some weight.

1553322222122121221111111112.content:
Pongo immediately thought that Thunderbolt had made some innocent mistake. Perhaps Thunderbolt had no idea how much a dog should eat, or perhaps Thunderbolt hadn't been too careful when he watched Rolly eat. Perhaps Rolly had persuaded Thunderbolt that he should have more food by some connivance. Perhaps even Thunderbolt had been convinced that Rolly was normal and didn't know how to make Rolly lose any weight. Or perhaps the two were unrelated. Perhaps because of Thunderbolt's injury and boredom he had gained weight, being unable to be exercised away by the scant activity that Thunderbolt was allowed; and perhaps Rolly truly couldn't lose weight now as he once had. But Pongo quickly discarded that thought. But one lurking suspicion ran through Pongo's mind continually: what if Thunderbolt had sabotaged Rolly's weight-loss efforts?
         Pongo immediately dismissed that as absurd, primarily because he had no evidence, and otherwise because Thunderbolt had no incentives for doing any such thing. But conspiracy theories have ways of appealing to one's innate sense of attaching malice to sheer ignorance or stupidity. So Pongo dismissed this conspiracy as baseless. Nevertheless, Pongo continuously monitored the food trough and watched to ascertain Rolly's habits.


         "I think that your dad's on to us," Thunderbolt remarked; Rolly glared at Thunderbolt for stating the obvious. "Yes, I'm aware," Rolly huffed, clearly enunciating each word to berate and demean Thunderbolt. "Do we want to use the oats?" Rolly inquired, having forgiven Thunderbolt for making dumb statements of obvious facts. Thunderbolt snickered, "I don't know, O Smartass; you tell me." Rolly scowled again, "Look, I said I was sorry for being a smartass. I have no justification for it, and I hope that you'll forgive me. But if you want me to make an executive decision, I will."
         Thunderbolt nodded, "Give your dad a week. He'll get impatient; and when he does, you can go back to your old habits." To that, Rolly prompted, "and if he doesn't?" "If he doesn't," Thunderbolt elaborated, "then, yes, you may and should. But be careful. Your father has heard the rumors and will no doubt put sentries up to guard here at some point."


         A week passed, but Pongo didn't give up his quest. So Rolly, sticking to the plan, carefully began to stick to the plan. Two weeks passed, and Pongo noticed with a broken heart that Rolly still hadn't lost any weight. Perhaps Rolly was right. When he had lost weight previously, he had been growing; and perhaps this was the natural full shape of his body. Perhaps he wasn't overweight at all, and perhaps he didn't need to lose weight. But still Pongo never gave up. He watched Thunderbolt eat his enormous portions from the bowl, plod off to the couch, and flop down on the floor because he could no longer force himself up on it anymore because his leg had so deteriorated.
         Things on Rolly's front looked no better for Rolly. The supply of oats was slowly shrinking because of the heavy crutch it gave Rolly while the poor dog was being deprived of food. Rolly's weight gain became anemic compared to what it had once been, but still he waited out his father. But Rolly made a mistake one night when he was preparing to get some oats from the shed.

         Rolly was very careful to be wary of intruders. He knew his siblings were smart enough to get downwind of him, so he knew he had to rely on sight and constantly shifting directions. Thunderbolt told Rolly that he was being to thorough and that he would be seen one day. And indeed, one night Rolly was seen pacing around the barn by…
1553322222122121221111111112.title: Innocent mistake.

15533222221221212211111111122.content:
Perhaps Rolly had been too cautious, but his father Pongo saw him one night pacing outside of the barn. It was a night in early June, a warm, humid, summer night that called for open windows to let in a breeze lest the house feel too stifling. Pongo usually didn't have trouble with the heat, and the cold usually bother him more; but that night he couldn't sleep. He considered walking around, but decided against such a course of action given that a walk would only make him more hot; so he decided to go roll around in the dewy grass to cool himself off.
         Having gone outside to do just that, he spotted his son prowling around the barn. But given that Rolly hadn't changed his course or flinched in any noticeable way, Pongo concluded that Rolly hadn't noticed Pongo. Indeed, Rolly hadn't. Although he had only eaten a few hours previous, Rolly was hungry again and had wanted a snack before bed, just enough to last himself through the night. He wasn't carefully watching because he didn't really expect anyone to notice or care enough to see what he was doing.
         But Pongo had noticed, so Rolly was unaware of his father's presence. Pongo lay stock still until Rolly had moved on. Pongo hoped that his son would be too lazy to check on any disturbance if he even sensed one. Rolly trudged heavily and sleepily around the barn a few more times before he went inside. Pongo waited a minute; and having realized that Rolly wasn't coming out for a while, Pongo decided to follow.
         One of the first sounds that Pongo heard was the distinct sound of a dog's paws on wood. Pongo thought that that noise was just Rolly's wishing to have the inaccessible food in the storage closet when he heard a distinct click followed by a creak of rusty hinges swinging. Had Rolly really gotten into the food closet? Pongo dismissed the thought before he peered into the door of the barn.
         The door to the food storeroom was ajar, and Pongo heard the distinct sounds of Rolly's ripping something, a sound followed by the distince sound of someone's eating. The barn was dark, and Pongo didn't want to give away his position. But halfway through the barn, Pongo stabbed his paw on something sharp, "AH, DAMN IT!" He howled in agony. The sound of eating immediately stopped, and Rolly poked his face through the door, or did something with the door given its squeak. "Dad?" Rolly asked, with a note of genuine panic, "are you ok?" "Yes, yes, I'll be ok," Pongo muttered, but his paw was too injured for use. "Be careful," Rolly whispered, "There's a shard of broken glass here somewhere." "Yes, son, it's in my foot!" Pongo wanted to scream, but instead said it at a mild level in a harsh tone to compensate.
         "Come on, Dad; let me help you. Or at least, let me get help," Rolly pleaded. "Don't ask me, son; just go; do it already," Pongo scream-whispered. And so Rolly ran as fast as he could, which was not that fast given his girth; and he bounded inside to his master's room. Rolly had taken precautions of locking the storage door before he had left, so he was safe on that front. But Rolly grabbed his master's leg by the pants and dragged his helpless master down to the kitchen, where he ran ahead while his master fumbled for a flashlight before catching up to Rolly halfway up the hill to the barn, where Rolly, Roger noticed, looked almost out of breath, and panting heavily.
         When Roger smelled the blood, he saw his first Dalmatian in a pool of it with a shard of something stuck in his paw. Roger nearly fainted before he grabbed Pongo and whisked him in his car to the vet after he had stopped the bleeding.


         Roger waited frantically while he stood outside the vet's office, waiting for the vet himself to arrive. The clerk at the desk was uncertified for doing anything like what was required. Roger was dreaming that Pongo had been struck in a major vein and was bleeding beyond fix. Roger was hoping that that wasn't the case, but was fearing that it was.
         When the vet finally arrived, Roger hurriedly and emotionally explained what was wrong to a bleary-eyed vet who nodded and tried to assauge Roger's fears to little avail before wheeling Pongo into the operating room.
         Roger waited and waited for an age before the vet came back…
15533222221221212211111111122.title: Pongo.

choices: They should confess to every one about what they have been doing...
They should let Pongo in on their plan...
155332222212212122111111111221.content:
Hearing this news, there was a large sign of relief in the entire family.

While Pongo is a determined and strong willed Dalmatian, Cause of this operation, Pongo's leg and paw was placed in a Cast, for the stitches to heal, and a Cone was placed about his head to go with it.

Since Pongo needed to have his paw heal, this did mean that Pongo wouldn' be as active as he usually would be.
Perdita herself made every effort to try and help Pongo, when ever she saw him; from helping him walk to even bringing kibble to him.

Rolly watches as Pongo & Perdita st together and Perdita trying to nose some more kibble to Pongo, to help keep his strength up.
It is cause of his plan with Thunderbolt, which cause this to happen, and Rolly knows that Pongo being laid up is cause of him. It would be practically impossible not to feel even a little bit of guilt about Pongo's leg.

He watches Pongo eat the Kibble, and considers some thing.

Soon, Rolly finds Thunderbolt.
"Erm...Thunderbolt?" Rolly asks; "I think we need to do some thing, about Dad?"

Thunderbolt himself hd an anxious look on his muzzle too, but looking at Rolly, he slowly asked; "What are you thinking there, Rolly?"

Rolly suggests...
155332222212212122111111111221.title: "Pongo will make it."

155332222212212122111111111222.content:
"Pongo has lost a copious amount of blood," the vet sighed as he walked back into the waiting room. "I stemmed the bleeding after I had removed the shard of glass," he continued, "but the stitches are fragile and Pongo is stable, but in dire condition. I will keep him until he awakes; but until then, you should go home and rest." Roger stared uncomprehendingly: how could that little shard have caused his beloved dog so much pain? Roger refused the vet's offer to leave; the vet then shrugged and allowed Roger to sit in the operating room with Pongo.
         A vet-tech walked in and relieved the doctor of sitting there. "He'll be fine, I'm sure," the vet-tech whispered. She was a middle-aged woman of perhaps fifty, Roger didn't dare ask, however, who was thin with a perfectly proprtioned body for Roger's taste. Roger found some solace in her words, "I'm sure this happens regularly," Roger chuckled, "so why am I panicking?" The woman smiled, "At least now you're out out of that sombre mood you were in but a moment ago. I'm Linda, just so you know." Roger's head snapped up, "Oh, yes, where are my manners? I'm Roger, and you know Pongo."
         Linda gave a wan smile, "Yes, good to know your name. And, yes, I do know Pongo. I'm sorry we had to meet under these dire circumstances." Roger nodded and looked back at Pongo, who seemed only a bit uncomfortable in the life-support equipment. Roger then sat back down and nodded off to sleep.

         Roger awoke to Linda's frantic whispers, "Roger, get up! Pongo's dying!" Roger snapped awake and stood immediately. The veterinarian stood, trying to administer something to a drugged Pongo, whose mouth seemed sealed shut. "What's wrong?" Roger could only feebly croak. "Pongo's having a heart attack!" Linda shouted. Pongo's cardiac monitor grew more feeble with each heartbeat, Roger thought. And with each paaing moment, the ekg grew more and more feeble until it completely flat-lined.
         The vet and Linda both tried to resuscitate Pongo to no avail. After several minutes, the vet stepped away, looked at Roger in a bleary-eyed way and whispered, "I'm sorry, sir: Pongo is dead by cardiac arrest caused by a blood-clot, probably from his leg." It took Roger until the end of the vet's sentence to realize what was happening; then he blacked out.
         When Roger came to, he thought that he had woken from an awful nightmare. But when he saw Pongo, not breathing and cold to the touch, lying on the table, he knew that what he had seen was real indeed. Pongo was dead. There was no way around that horrible, terrifying, and morbid fact. Roger knew that he would have to cope with that. So he took Pongo's corpse, placed it in a shroud, and drove back home with it in his car.

         Having arrived back home, Roger got the wooden cross that he had gotten from the little church down the road, took a shovel, dug a grave, and gently placed Pongo in it. Roger bawled the entire time. Anita eventually came out, saw what Roger was doing, and wept with him. Perdita knew what was going on, as did Thunderbolt; but none of the children but Rolly seemed to get what was happening. When the funeral was complete, the couple went inside.
         For a couple of days, Roger didn't feel like eating anything; so he gave his food when Anita wasn't looking to Thunderbolt, who appreciated the rich human food with his whole heart. Although it never satisfied him, Thunderbolt always had an appetite for more. But after that couple of days of grief, Roger recovered his appetite, which at first disappointed Thunderbolt. But Roger lost his appetite again a few days later, after eating twice what he normally ate in a day for a week. But then, for a couple of days here and there, Roger would lose his appetite and slip his plates under the table to Thunderbolt.
         Perdita was also never the same. She stopped doting over her children, became more cold and irritable, and stopped caring as much about what her children did, an approach thatbsuited Rolly just fine. Rolly, to cope with the grief, buried his nose into more food and ate more than he could have forced himself to eat. Rolly just wanted the excuse to eat; and although he loved his father, he moved on quite quickly. Thunderbolt also needed the pretense if he was going to keep eating like he was and not exercising.
         But Thunderbolt and Rolly slowly put on more weight for a little while until…
155332222212212122111111111222.title: "I don't know."

1553322222122121221111111112221.content:
Rolly lay on his side, napping to digest his breakfast when he felt the gentle touch of some paw, so he lifted his head and turned it to see who had tapped his exorbitant roll of fat that formed whenever Rolly lay on his side. Having seen his mother standing and glaring at him. Rolly tried to stand up, but got no further than where he had started, hampered by the mass of his abdomen. The pitiful dalmatian then remembered that he had to first roll himself onto his chest and belly, a process that left him a bit short of breath; he then scrambled with his front paws to get himself into a sitting position before he finally began to shift his weight as far forward as it would go before he managed to lift his bulk off the ground.
         Normally, this process was not as much of a rigamarole; but Rolly's full stomach made catching a deep breath difficult; and sleep made him groggy. After about thirty seconds of this struggle, Rolly finally managed to pant, "Yes, Mom?"
         Perdita looked a bit shaken at her son's display of such an obvious weakness, but she let no more concern show in her face than was already present. "Yes, Rolly," she whispered as she shed a crocodile tear, "It's about your father. Patch, and others have confirmed, that you were not in the house on the night your father…passed." Here, Perdita shed a genuine tear, but not becaue of love of her lost husband, but out of loathing of her son's perceived conspiracy in this plot.
         Rolly nodded, willing to listen standing, despite that his knees were beginning to ache; and he dared not ask to sit, lest his mother go off about his softness and weakness. "No," he sighed, "I remember that I was in the barn. I was the first one who heard father after he cut his foot. I tried to save him!" Perdita nodded, throughly unconvinced by her son's charade, "How did you avoid the glass?" Rolly knew he needed a better answer than "luck" or some other stupid answer. It had indeed been luck, but Rolly knew that his mother wouldn't be placated by such a simple answer. So he fibbed.
         "I saw the shards when a stray beam of moonlight flashed on the shards." There were windows all around the barn, so this answer would be plausible to his mother. But what Rolly sensed would be his mother's next question would be harder to have a convincing answer to. And surely enough, Perdita then asked, "How did you not hear your father's approach?"
         Rolly pondered but remained calm for a moment before he answered honestly: "I don't know. You know that I've never been observant. And dad was, I'm almost certain, trying to spy on me--not maliciously, just to see what I was doing. When he howled in pain was the first time I realized he was present, and you know how I get around food. But, Mom, asking someone to disprove a negative is a logical fallacy." Rolly's mother even chuckled at this, but Rolly knew it was a derisive laughter, one mocking, not supporting him. But, in truth, she knew how he was with food--how he entered a trancelike state when food was within a five-foot radius.
         But she had to have someone else to blame. "Damn you," she snarled, taking Rolly aback, "why was I given you, the worthless sack of heart disease and diabetes that you are." And with that, Perdita stormed off, leaving Rolly silently sobbing at the ad hominem his mother had just hurled at him. What she said Rolly knew to be true, but it was nevertheless a grevious insult. And that hurt.
         Rolly was still trying to control the endorphin-enfused water flowing freely down his face when Thunderbolt came hobbling in before he thumped his meaty back side down on the ground with a thump that knocked Rolly out of his nauseous melancholy. Thunderbolt knew something was terribly wrong, so he immediately panted--because he lacked the breath to do anything more forceful, "What--what can--I d-do to h-help." Rolly knew that his face was a mess, so he lay down beside his companion and told him what had just happened, but deliberately leaving out the final insult. Thunderbolt immediately sensed that Rolly was telling most--but not all--the truth. But he didn't want to press the issue further.
         Rolly shook his head, calmed his sobbing, which had left him out of breath anyway, and said with a firm, somber voice, "No, Thunderbolt. Nothing that I would ever ask you to do." Thunderbolt again decided not to press the issue. But Rolly decided to continue, "Besides, it isn't anything you could help me with anyway. I need to control my own weight; that's all." Thunderbolt nodded, but was aghast that his partner in crime would up and abandon him on such a whim, because Rolly was not whimsical. Perhaps he was just in a state of furor and unwilling to control his rage, so he was just spewing idiotic rage.
         But what if he were serious? What if what he had said had indeed been meditated upon beforehand? Thunderbolt revelled in this new bombshell revelation. If Rolly lost weight, Thunderbolt would lose all credibility. He had to find some way to lessen or slow the damage. "And how will you do it--lose weight, I mean?" Rolly paused for a moment before he declared:…
1553322222122121221111111112221.title: Perdita asks about that night

15533222221221212211111111122212.content:
When Rolly stated this, Thunderbolt felt like he had just had his body crushed like his leg under the stage-light. This plan was serious and well-considered, not a rash rage-induced throw-away statement that was not meant to be taken seriously. Thunderbolt knew he had to do something; so he nodded his head and mused, "Ah, I see. It's probably for the best that you gently coax yourself away from the food that you like so much."
         Thunderbolt understood that Rolly knew that the former was going to be a hindrance to the latter's efforts, so Thunderbolt needed to find a way to penetrate that guard. He had to initially seem against the plan but seem to come around to it; so he added, "I think you're a good weight just the way you are; but I'm glad that you decided to lose weight slowly and incrementally and not quickly. I don't know if I like this plan, but you can do as you will."
         Rolly sighed, "I appreciate the compliments, your frankness, and your willingness to stay out of the way. But I intend to do this anyway. I need to. To win affection and trust from my mother." Thunderbolt nodded, realizing the piece of the puzzle Rolly had left out. "Did your mother insult you?" Thunderbolt mused jokingly. And by the way Rolly's cheek flushed bright red and by the ways he turned away in shame, Thunderbolt knew that he had hit the nail on the head. He scooted over and thoroughly apologized to Rolly, "Hey, I didn't mean to embarrass you. I just wanted to understand your sudden 180 on your life's ambition."
         Rolly turned, seemingly just remembering that not cowing to his mother's will and eating as much as he pleased was indeed his life's goal. But his resolve returned, his eyes hardening, "You won't change my mind on this matter. I will lose the weight." Thunderbolt retired, seemingly defeated. Some time later, Thunderbolt got up and wandered slowly, partially deliberately, partially because it embarrassed him when his flesh around his ribs shook violently when he moved any faster, to the deserted food trough, which was around the corner from Rolly.
         Rolly could not ignore the slow, contrived movements that Thunderbolt took to raise himself from the floor. And Rolly knew that there were only two things Thunderbolt would be doing in that direction: getting food or relieving himself. And from where he heard the footsteps stop, Rolly deduced that Thunderbolt had stopped for the former. And having not forgotten his diet, Rolly tried to ignore the sound of Thunderbolt scarfing down a midday meal.
         Eventually, however, Rolly got up, unable to resist the sound of scraping food any longer. Thunderbolt had only been digging around with his nose for a minute or two when he heard the slow footsteps of Rolly, and the Shepherd decided to force himself to eat. Rolly, who had usually eaten the midday meal before he had started his diet, now felt the urge to eat something. No, he realized, not to eat, but to placate his stomach. Thunderbolt now feigned surprise as he looked up, nodded, and walked back into the living room to let Rolly make his own decisions.
         When the large Shepherd had finally sauntered out of the room, Rolly stood in front of the tantalizing food: would he give in and abandon his diet before he had even started or would he stick to his diet and resist the urge to gorge with abandon on the present food. Rolly stood, fretting over one of the toughest decisions he had ever made in his life. He stood petrified for a while, perhaps five minutes or more, agonizing over his decision before his knees made a decision for him. He had to lie down to rest before he could make a decision. Eventually, he stood, with a straining effort, and gingerly padded into the living room.
         He had done it! Rolly realized. He had resisted food for the first time in his life when he had not been too full to eat any more. Small steps, Rolly knew, were the only way to achieving any goal. Hours passed, and the gurgle of Rolly's stomach grew more frequent and irritable. Thunderbolt felt almost perfectly the hunger that Rolly felt when the Dalmatian's stomach growled in that way. Thunderbolt had been unfed at midday throughout his acting career, which left him feeling ravenous for dinner; it was not a pleasant sensation.
         Dinnertime rolled around. Rolly felt the growl in his stomach grow only more desperate as he waited for everyone to finish dinner. Rolly knew how much he should eat. He would eat until he was pleasantly sated, but not overfull. Before anyone else came for dinner, Rolly performed his elaborate routine to stand and waddled over to the food trough, just recently filled by Roger. And Pongo ate rapidly until he had begun to feel satisfied, but not overfull. And he knew he had to stop. So he did momentarily, but he knew he couldn't agonize over his decision like he had at lunch, otherwise, he would fail and gorge himself more.
         So he made a decision quickly. He moved himself away from the food. The sensation was dizzying. He had succeeded again, Rolly thought to himself. He just had to slowly wean himself off the food. He just had to keep doing what he was doing, and he would lose the weight he wanted. He had to keep reducing the rations, and he would succeed.
         But after a few days, Rolly found that the nagging urge to glut himself with food was just as strong as it ever had been, if not stronger. Rolly knew that he had to persevere, but his weak flesh wanted to ignore his strong mind. Prudence and temperance be damned! shouted Rolly's stomach to his mind. Shut up! Rolly growled back at his stomach. Rolly had to decide what he wanted to do. He needed to talk to someone.
15533222221221212211111111122212.title: "Slowly and cautiously."

155332222212212122111111111222121.content:
Despite his reservations and his knowledge of Thunderbolt's biases, Rolly decided that he had to seek the corpulent Shepherd's advice. Five days of regimented dieting had shot Rolly's will to continue with his plan. The obese Dalmatian had just made his second round of food cuts, a further demoralization for his cause. But he had decided to persevere in his austerity. Rolly knew that the weight would come off slowly at this rate, if at all. It would take a year or more at this rate, but Rolly knew that he was now at a critcal crossroads for his future; so he wanted advice.
         Thunderbolt felt a paw poke gently at his hill-shaped abdomen. The poke didn't get to his ribs before the massive dog awoke. "Thunderbolt," came Rolly's familiar voice, "I need your advice about my diet." Thunderbolt looked up and heaved himself with some difficulty onto his stomach and after a deep breath, he exhaled, "Well, I can't say that I'll be useful to you. But what do you want to ask me?"
         Rolly lay down and took his own deep breath, "I'm at a dilemma. My will to continue dieting is weak, at best. I was wondering whether I should indulge my stomach or stay strong and soldier through my indecision." Thunderbolt was immediately excited by the news and let his ears perk to let Rolly know that his position on Rolly's diet had not changed. But Thunderbolt then gave an honest answer, "Rolly, you've always been so decisive. I know you can musterl the willpower to resist your temptation. But if you must give in, make the giving in at one meal time and not too frequently. That always was how I heard my humans say to diet. But you have to remember not to give in too frequently."
         Rolly nodded, but before he got up to walk away, he asked, "And how frequently is too frequently." Thunderbolt considered his answer before he responded, "Well, obviously it can't come every day; but you have to try and make it as long as you can. You have to really try." Rolly nodded, grinning, pleased that Thunderbolt had given him helpful advice, in spite of his obvious biases. Rolly had noticed how Thunderbolt's face had lit up when Rolly said that his will to continue was weakening. But this fact left a seed of doubt in Rolly's mind. The advice all seemed earnest enough, and Rolly suspected that he knew which parts of Thunderbolt's account. The cheat day.
         Rolly suspected that the cheat day thing was false--that he had to keep soldiering on. But Rolly didn't think Thunderbolt was sabotaging his efforts directly, but he knew he had to try to keep soldiering on. Rolly decided eventually that Thunderbolt's advice was too intuitive, too obvious. But perhaps Thunderbolt had no idea what worked either, that all he had was speculation. But Rolly played devil's advocate with himself and challenged his previous assertion with the fact that he had no better ideas. And speculation was better than nothing at this point.
         So Rolly decided to try Thunderbolt's advice, despite his reservations. He soldiered on for two days more; and on the seventh day after he had started his diet, Rolly finally folded and gave in to his temptations, engorging on all the food he could feed upon, vowing that his third round of food cuts would come the next day. And, in spite of how such promises usually turned out, it did indeed come. And in the middle of the week, Rolly made his fourth round of cuts to his intake.
         At this point, his stomach snarled rapaciously and whined that it was being denied of its rightful inheritance. Rolly, no longer able to sustain the constant complaining of his stomach, on the twelth day indulged his stomach until it screamed for mercy for the opposite reason.
         After Rolly had taken a day to indulge himself, he realized that his "indulgence days" were quickly running closer together. He promised himself that he would only indulge himself once every seven days, on the seventh day. So he had used his indulgence of the week, Rolly pondered sullenly.
155332222212212122111111111222121.title: Thunderbolt

1553322222122121221111111112221211.content:
Despite his early weakness, Rolly had managed to stick to his diet, in spite of his almost constant, gnawing hunger that seemed to have a mind of his own. But he was losing patience. He had reached a level of food austerity needed to maintain a normal weight approved by his family, especially his mother. But that amount rested on the presumption that Rolly would actually lose weight. Much to his chagrin, and to Thunderbolt's tacit, but open, pleasure and amusement, Rolly seemed not to have lost any significant weight, maybe ten pounds at most.
         Rolly's spirit had been crushed by his dismal results. "Perhaps you need more time," Thunderbolt had stated, trying to console his gloomy companion, "you didn't gain the weight overnight; and because losing weight is harder than gaining it, you can't possibly expect quick results." Rolly knew that Thunderbolt was telling the truth; and although Rolly didn't usually let his feelings distract him from his thoughts, this truth was unpleasant given that it seemed like he had been dieting for quite a while. He knew it had been a mere 8 weeks, but those had caused immense pain, physical and emotional.
         Rolly didn't feel better, only worse. "This a medium-to-long investment," Thunderbolt had proclaimed, with the arrogant superiority of someone who thinks he knows everything. But in spite of himself and his own will, Rolly had trouble planning for the future--he was an "in-the-now" kind of guy. He didn't want to sacrifice now for medium or, worse, long term pleasure and prosperity, especially when his best friend wasn't.
         It wasn't even as if Thunderbolt were suffering for his lack of foresight. Although he was years older than Rolly, and had a crippled leg, Thunderbolt seemed to pay no price for his weight. Thunderbolt knew this was untrue, but he knew how to hide his problems from Rolly. But after losing only maybe fifteen pounds, Thunderbolt noted that Rolly could already roll over much more easily than he had at fifteen pounds heavier. His routine for standing up and walking were less elaborate than they had been, and he could now walk faster and didn't have to breath as hard after a walk to the food bowl or outside to relieve himself. These small differences made Thunderbolt mildly envious of Rolly.
         The shepherd didn't know why, because he could force himself to lose weight; but Thunderbolt couldn't suppress his instictive urge to have his cake and eat it too. He wanted to be able to eat as much as he wanted and not get fat or have any of the repercussions associated with that weight. No, that fat, Thunderbolt corrected himself. Thunderbolt knew his desire was impossible and irrational, but at the same time, he wished it was so.
         Having thought of getting up, Thunderbolt decided that he should go relieve himself while Rolly was sulking by himself outside. And so began the increasingly elaborate routine Thunderbolt used to get himself up. He began to roll over and eventually managed to heave his hind legs under his massive belly that hung over his feet and made a pear shape from the base of his tail to his shoulders. Thunderbolt began to scoot his front legs backward until they were constrained by the limits of his massive chest and stomach. The corpulent Shepherd then pushed his hind legs back as far as they would go before he pushed up with those legs as hard as he could, gently lifting his butt from the ground until he was fully standing, his inufed hind leg, howvever, felt especially bad.
         He took a step forward, more of a shuffle, with that foot. Deciding that he had just sat on it for too long, Thunderbolt began another step; but this time, he felt a searing pain in his injured back leg. And when he moved the opposite front leg from his injured leg, with his center-of-gravity on his injured leg, he felt a shooting pain in that leg before it buckled and collapsed, forcing Thunderbolt with a massive thump into the ground. Thunderbolt nearly howled in pain as loudly as he could before he stifled the urge at the last moment. He wasn't greivously injured, but his back legs hurt like hell.
         Thunderbolt knew better than to try standing again, a premonition confirmed by the approach of Rolly's heavy, plodding footsteps. Rolly didn't have to shuffle like had had to anymore. A sight that made Thunderbolt green with envy. "What happened?" Rolly asked, in a concerned manner. "Sorry," Thunderbolt answered hastily, "I thought I needed to go outside when I realized I didn't; and I sat down a bit faster than I meant to." Rolly suspected Thunderbolt had been leaving something out, but he had no idea what it was.
         Rolly sat carefully next to Thunderbolt and saw that Thunderbolt grimaced slightly before the rotund shepherd smiled, "What's going on out there?" Rolly sighed, "The idiots are playing stupid games. I've been listening to Roger complain about the coal-miners' strikes around the country. I have no idea what 'coal' or a 'miner' is though. So I was bored and came in here." Thunderbolt chuckled, explaining to Rolly what "coal" and "miners" were, and why they were so important.
         But Rolly pondered for a moment before he turned and looked at Thunderbolt with the sort of grim determination one wears on one's face before one goes into battle, "Thunderbolt, will you diet with me? I need a partner. I need someone to give me resolve. So will you?"
1553322222122121221111111112221211.title: Weeks pass.

15533222221221212211111111122212111.content:
Thunderbolt nodded. He knew that he ought to lose a few kilos if he wanted to feel better and move around better. But hunger was difficult for him, painful. Suddenly, Thunderbolt had a memory dragged to the surface by the thought of losing weight.

         Thunderbolt was back in the recording studio, after one of his taping sessions. His vet had come to check up on him, a routine examination to make sure that Thunderbolt was still physically fit. The check-up had proceeded normally, with an exchange of pleasantries and some vaccine boosters and a talk about routine schedules, sleep, and behavior. Eventually, Thunderbolt got put on a scale and weighed. "41" read the scale. The vet looked discouraged. "Sir," the vet quavered, "I'm afraid your dog is 41 kilos. He should weigh at most 37 kilos, and I would like to see him closer to 35. Do you think you could do that?"
         Thunderbolt's manager, Reed, nodded and thanked the vet. When the vet left, Reed had glared--not looked sympathetically or disapprovingly--but glared with all his wrath. Thunderbolt remembered shrinking away from his manager and whimpering pitifully. Thenceforth, until Reed got Thunderbolt down to 33 kilos, Thunderbolt was given a half rations once a day. Not one of his normal meals, but half of one not twice but once a day. Those six weeks had been miserable, an undesireable memory and Thunderbolt's reason for his hoarding of food.

         Thunderbolt came out of his memroial daydream eventually, but not until Rolly walked away chuckling, "Tomorrow, Thunderbolt, we begin." Thunderbolt knew then what he had to do. Thunderbolt knew that Rolly was demoralized. He knew that the poor dog was suffering not just from hunger, but from the repeated humiliations from his family members, who all liked to poke and prod at Rolly's fat rolls to make fun of him maliciously.
         Thunderbolt was surprised no one had bothered to come after him yet. Perhaps he had drawn sympathy from his injury, immunity from his movie-star status, or perhaps it was just because he just wasn't a member of the family. Thunderbolt knew from experience, that wisdom of unlettered men, that families criticized each other more harshly than they did outsiders, at least good families did.
         But none of these things mattered. Rolly did laugh at his family, and had always done so, and would, Thunderbolt hoped, continue to do so, not because he didn't understand the joke, but because the laughing was the only way to get the others to stop laughing at him. Thunderbolt thenrealized that he ought to go and relieve himself soon or he would go on the carpet. He stretched and yawned; heaved his massive stomach onto the floor between, over, and just outside his paws; and rocked his weight back and forth until hebwas on his feet.
         This time, he was careful with his back leg, moving it gingerly and as quickly as he could, and shuffled outside, maneuvering his soft, gelatinous body through the doggy door built for two Dalmatianss to walk abreast through it at the same time. But Thunderbolt's flanks gently brushed both sides of the door ever so slightly at the same time. That occurence had never happened before, Thunderbolt grimaced.
         Going back inside, he was careful not to brush against the doggy door's sides, because it hurt his flanks. Having gotten into the kitchen, he noticed that Roger was there; so Thunderbolt went into the living room and flopped down heavily, panting for a moment from his exertion, his back right knee ached from the weight mounted on it. Perhaps he did need a diet, Thunderbolt thought, it would help him with his mobility. So perhaps he would give the diet a chance.

         Rolly sat before the food bowl, unwilling to give up his attention to the food before him. Resisting the food was excruciating, a herculean task. Tomorrow, he thought, at least he would have Thunderbolt's help to give him resolve. Today was Rolly's cheat day, but Rolly knew that his cheat days were causing him to stay hungry when he was eating his reduced, no, normal, Rolly corrected himself, portions. He knew he would also have to indulge less on his cheat days if he were to be less hungry throughout the week; nevertheless, he countered, his cheat day wouldn't feel like an indulgence if he were to restrain himself. And the restrain defeated the purpose of a cheat day at all.
         But Rolly turned and walked away.
